article.headline: Montana 66, Idaho State 62
article.story:
MISSOULA, Mont. (AP) -- This is just what the Lady Griz were
after.

Win the Big Sky Conference tournament and earn the league's
automatic berth in the NCAA women's basketball tournament, where
they can play a first-round game on their home court.

"You spend your life building to a moment like this," said
Julie Deming, who finished with nine points and nine rebounds in
Montana's 66-62 victory over Idaho State. "We're all best friends.
We feed off each other. We work hard. I'm gonna love these girls
for the rest of my life."

Tournament MVP Brooklynn Lorenzen had 13 points, eight assists
and several clutch baskets to end Idaho State runs in the
championship game. Montana advances to the NCAA tournament for the
first time in four years, after making 11 appearances in 13 years
between 1988 and 2000.

"I wouldn't say they amazed me, because I expected a lot out of
this team," said UM coach Robin Selvig. "But to get 26-27 wins is
not easy. It's tougher than it was a few years ago. Plus, I put
together one of our most difficult schedules."

Deming, who missed last season with an injury, is the only
current Montana player who has played in an NCAA tournament.

The injury "might have been a blessing in disguise," Deming
said. "I'll never forget the feeling (of playing in the NCAA's)
and now all these girls can experience it, too."

Montana (27-4), which has a 17-game winning streak and a 22-game
home winning streak, will learn its first-round opponent when the
tournament pairings are announced Sunday afternoon. Montana will
play host to first- and second-round games on March 20 and 22.

Juliann Keller had 17 points and Hollie Tyler added 14 points
for Montana, which led 63-52 with 2:51 remaining on a basket by
Tyler.

Idaho State (20-8) outscored Montana 10-3 the rest of the way,
including five points from Annie Anderson, who led the Bengals with
22 points.

"I'd like to think if we'd had two more minutes, we'd have had
them," Anderson said. "But there's only 40 minutes in the game."

Lindy Whitley added 13 points, Christa Brossman finished with 10
and Molly Hays had seven points and 11 rebounds for the Bengals,
who won just six games last season.

"For us to come within four points of the NCAA tournament, when
we were picked to finish seventh (in the eight-team league) by the
coaches and seventh by the media, I just couldn't be prouder of
this team than any team I've been associated with," said
first-year ISU coach Jon Newlee.

The Lady Griz jumped to an early 18-7 lead on a basket by Jody
McLeod before a basket by Heidi Gifford, back-to-back 3-pointers by
Anderson -- her first of the season -- and two free throws by
Anderson pulled the Bengals within 18-17 with 9:11 left in the
half.

The game continued that way, with Montana building leads and
Idaho State using 3-pointers to rally.

"We were on the verge of getting away from them a couple
times," Selvig said. "We'd get it to 10 or 11 and we couldn't
quite do it."

Idaho State made 10-of-25 3-pointers, far better shooting than
the past two games, in which they were a combined 5-of-47. The
Bengals led just once, at 5-4 after a 3-pointer by Christa Brossman
just three minutes into the game.

Montana held a 38-27 halftime lead and built a 44-30 lead on a
basket by Tyler with 17:26 remaining. Idaho State got a basket from
Anderson and 3-pointers from Laraine Barron, Hays and Whitley to
pull within 46-41 with 15 minutes to play.

Keller had five points in a 7-2 Montana run that made the score
53-43 on two free throws by Lorenzen with 10:49 to play.

Lorenzen had several key shots to end ISU rallies in the second
half, including a driving layup, a steal and full-court layup and a
short jumper.

"This is my last chance," Lorenzen said. "I'm done after
this. I didn't want to go out being sad. I don't want any regrets
when it's over."

Tyler, Keller and Anderson also were named to the all-tournament
team, along with Sheila Hutchison of Montana State and Kathleen
Nygaard of Eastern Washington.

Idaho State coach Newlee said the school's administration
believes the Bengals have earned a spot in the Women's National
Invitation Tournament.

"I hope so," he said. "We deserve to be in the NIT. The last
three years I was at Hawaii we were in the NIT and this team is
every bit as good as the teams we had at Hawaii."

Montana, which won all 14 of its Big Sky games this season, beat
Idaho State 77-66 at ISU in January and 65-62 in Missoula in
February.

"I thought it was a really good basketball game," said Selvig.
"Give Idaho State a ton of credit. We got out of the gates well,
but they weathered it and fought back. They played well and my kids
did, too. It's tough to beat a good team three times in one year."
